docs.title: 📚 My Technical Notes
docs.text: Welcome to my personal knowledge base. Here, I document new technologies, tools, and concepts I’m learning to grow as a software engineer.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
• Keep a clear, organized record of what I learn.
  • Create a quick reference I can revisit anytime.
  • Share knowledge in a structured, accessible way.

docs.title: Topics Covered
docs.text:
• Programming languages and frameworks
  • DevOps tools and automation
  • Cloud platforms
  • Software design and architecture

docs.title: How to Navigate
docs.text: Use the menu on the left to explore topics. Each section contains: - Overview of the technology - Step-by-step examples - Screenshots or diagrams - Key takeaways

docs.title: First Topic
docs.text: Start with Jenkins — an automation server for building, testing, and deploying software.

docs.title: Jenkins
docs.text: Automation platform that lets you build, test, and deploy automations using pipelines.

docs.title: Jenkins Infrastructure
docs.text:
• Master Server = Controls the pipelines & schedules builds
  • Agents/Minions Servers = Run the builds

docs.title: Jenkins Build Types
docs.text: 1. Freestyle Builds - shell scripts that are run on servers based on specific events. 2. Pipeline Builds - Use Jenkins files to define declaritively on how to deploy the build in different stages.

docs.title: Jenkins GUI
docs.text:
• Manage Jenkins: This contains all of the settings that you need for your Jenins instance such as plugins, global settings, etc.
  • System Configuration/Configure System
  • System Configuration/Manage Plugins
  • System Configuration/Manage Nodes & Cloud: This is where you setup agents
  • Security/Manage Credentials: This where you store SSH keys or API tokens
  • Tools and Actions/Prepare for Shutdown: You need to use this when you are performing and upgrade or maintanence if you just shutdown the server without doing this step then you will interrupt jobs that are running.

docs.title: Setting up Freestyle Jenkins Projects
docs.text: 1. Go to the Jenkins Dashboard then click on New Item. The two most popular types of projects are freestyle and pipelines 2. Pick the type of job and give it a name. Make sure to not to put spaces in the name 3. From the build options: - Source Code Management is usually always Git and Jenkins will pull that repo that is specified here. You also will mention any branches if you need specific ones. - Then we have Build Triggers: You would usually using GitHub webhooks but you need to make sure the firewall or port is open on the Jenkins server so that it can work with the webhook. Build Periodically is used to build jobs on a schedule using cron jobs. - Build Enviornments 4. 5.
